questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Joel 1:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the progression of locust destruction and the call for mourning.
tips: Notice the four stages of locusts: cutting, swarming, hopping, and destroying (v.2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'awake, you drunkards, and weep' (v.4) for its emotional weight
The repetition of 'the locust has eaten' (v.2,3) emphasizes total devastation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT is happening, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it is happening (in relation to Judah's sin).
tips: Include the four stages of locust destruction (v.2)
Note the land mourning like a virgin without her bridegroom (v.5)
The cut off of grain and drink offerings (v.13) shows worship disruption

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the progression of locust destruction (v.2), the image of the land mourning (v.5), or the cut off of offerings (v.13).
tips: The four stages of locusts (v.2) show cumulative destruction leaving nothing behind
The land mourning like a virgin (v.5) connects physical devastation to spiritual desolation
The cut off of offerings (v.13) highlights the complete disruption of worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Joel trying to communicate to Judah through this passage of the locust plague?
tips: Joel calls Judah to repentance for their sin
The locust plague is God's judgment on unrepentant Judah
The passage points to national mourning and the need for restoration

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The four stages of locusts? Why the land is mourning? The cut off of offerings?
tips: The four stages of locusts (v.2) are a poetic device showing increasing destruction
The phrase 'a nation has come up against my land' (v.6) refers to God's judgment, not an external military invasion
The land mourning (v.5) is a metaphor for spiritual desolation due to sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Joel calls for repentance and mourning. What area of your life requires you to mourn and repent this week, as if the land is mourning?
tips: Consider a sin causing you to 'not weep' like the drunkards (v.4)
Think about what the locusts have eaten (v.2) and what you need to let go of
Pray for the spirit of repentance to come upon you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Ask God for repentance for Judah, and for the restoration of His people.
tips: Thank God for His judgment that brings us to repentance (v.14-16)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to bring the mourning of the land (v.5) to your heart
Ask God to restore what the locusts have eaten (v.10)

chapters.chapterTitle: The Day of the LORD and Call to Repentance

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Joel 2:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the urgent warning in verses 1-2 and the call to repentance in verses 12-13.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the day of the LORD' (v.1, 2, 10, 13)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of urgency in verses 1-2
The phrase 'rend your hearts and not your garments' (v.12) is a key phrase

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the LORD) is calling, WHAT (to repent), WHERE (Judah), and WHY (because the day of the LORD is near).
tips: Include the warning of the day of the LORD (v.1-2)
Note the call for repentance with fasting, weeping, and mourning (v.12-13)
Describe the promise of the outpouring of the Spirit (v.14-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning of the day of the LORD (v.1-2), the call to 'rend your hearts' (v.12-13), or the outpouring of the Spirit (v.14-16)?
tips: The phrase 'rend your hearts and not your garments' (v.12) emphasizes internal repentance over external rituals
The promise that even children and servants will prophesy (v.14) is a powerful sign of God's restoration
The contrast between the day of darkness (v.1-2) and the coming blessing (v.14) is striking

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Joel trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Joel is warning Judah of impending judgment but also offering a path to redemption through repentance
The call to 'rend your hearts' points to the need for genuine spiritual transformation
The outpouring of the Spirit at the end of the day of the LORD is a sign of God's grace and restoration

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'day of the LORD' (v.1), the 'great and powerful people' (v.3), or the 'outpouring of the Spirit' (v.14)?
tips: The 'day of the LORD' in Joel's context refers to a day of judgment and restoration, not a future eschatological event
The 'great and powerful people' (v.3) likely refers to the army of the enemy (e.g., Babylon) but the text says 'their like has never been before, nor will be again'
The outpouring of the Spirit (v.14) is a promise of the Holy Spirit's power that is fulfilled in the New Testament at Pentecost (Acts 2)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Joel calls for repentance with fasting, weeping, and mourning. What area of your life needs this kind of repentance this week?
tips: Consider a sin or habit that has been normalized in your life that needs to be addressed with genuine sorrow
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you 'rend your heart' (v.12) rather than just making external changes
Commit to one act of repentance that involves fasting or mourning for a specific sin

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His grace and mercy. Ask for the courage to repent and for the outpouring of His Spirit.
tips: Thank God for being 'gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love' (v.13)
Pray for the strength to 'rend your heart' and not just your garments (v.12)
Ask God to pour out His Spirit on you and others so that you can experience the signs of His restoration (v.14)
